message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles: Control Methods and Future Challenges
Paper Abstract: With the rapid development of computer technology, automatic control technology and communication technology, research on unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has attracted extensive attention from all over the world during the last decades. Particularly due to the demand of various civil applications, the conceptual design of UAV and autonomous flight control technology have been promoted and developed mutually. This paper is devoted to providing a brief review of the UAV control issues, including motion equations, various classical and advanced control approaches. The basic ideas, applicable conditions, advantages and disadvantages of these control approaches are illustrated and discussed. Some challenging topics and future research directions are raised.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about motion equations in physics:

## Overview of Equations of Motion

In physics, equations of motion are equations that describe the behavior of a physical system in terms of its motion as a function of time.(no content)A differential equation of motion, usually identified as some physical law (for example, F = ma), and applying definitions of physical quantities, is used to set up an equation to solve a kinematics problem.

## Mathematical Foundation

An equation of motion is a function of the position r of the object, its velocity (the first time derivative of r), and its acceleration (the second derivative of r), and time t.

## Newton's Laws of Motion

Newton's laws of motion are three physical laws that describe the relationship between the motion of an object and the forces acting on it. These include:

- A body remains at rest, or in motion at a constant speed in a straight line, unless it is acted upon by a force.
- At any instant of time, the net force on a body is equal to the body's acceleration multiplied by its mass or, equivalently, the rate at which the body's momentum is changing with time.
- If two bodies exert forces on each other, these forces have the same magnitude but opposite directions.

## Linear Motion Equations

In case of constant acceleration, the four physical quantities acceleration, velocity, time and displacement can be related by using the equations of motion. These relate velocity, acceleration, time, and displacement for objects moving in straight lines.

## Applications

Motion equations have broad applications across various types of motion including linear motion, circular motion, projectile motion, and harmonic oscillations in physics and engineering.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicles:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## Types and Characteristics

Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) include both autonomous (capable of operating without human input) drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs). There are also specialized variants, such as unmanned combat aerial vehicles (UCAVs), also known as combat drones, fighter drones or battlefield UAVs, which carry aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and/or aerial bombs.

## Historical Development

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.

## Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These include diverse uses such as aircraft maintenance, crop spraying since 1987 by Japanese farmers, and in the U.S. for crop spraying as they are often cheaper than full-sized helicopters, as well as search and rescue, infrastructure inspection, and wildlife monitoring.

I've gathered comprehensive information about Automatic Control Theory from the web search. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Scope

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems, with the aim to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

### How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP), with the difference between actual and desired value applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell, and was further advanced by Edward Routh, Charles Sturm, and Adolf Hurwitz, who contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; with PID control theory developed by Nicolas Minorsky from 1922 onwards.

### Real-World Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.

### Key Concepts

Fundamentally, there are two types of control loop: open-loop control (feedforward), and closed-loop control (feedback).

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Veronte Autopilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veronte_Autopilot"},{"title":"Autopilot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autopilot"},{"title":"Manned-unmanned teaming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manned-unmanned_teaming"},{"title":"Micro air vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_air_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Range safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Range_safety"},{"title":"Pipistrel Nuuva V300 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pipistrel_Nuuva_V300"},{"title":"Aurora Goldeneye - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aurora_Goldeneye"},{"title":"V/STOL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VTOL"}]

I found comprehensive information about Autonomous Flight Control. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

One way to achieve autonomous control employs multiple control-loop layers, as in hierarchical control systems.(no content)For flight control, low-layer loops tick as fast as 32,000 times per second, while higher-level loops may cycle once per second.

## Control Architecture

The principle is to decompose the aircraft's behavior into manageable "chunks", or states, with known transitions. Hierarchical control system types range from simple scripts to finite state machines, behavior trees and hierarchical task planners.(no content)The most common control mechanism used in these layers is the PID controller which can be used to achieve hover for a quadcopter by using data from the IMU to calculate precise inputs for the electronic speed controllers and motors.

## Software Architecture

Modern UAVs run a software stack that ranges from low-level firmware that directly controls actuators, to high level flight planning. At the lowest level, firmware directly controls reading from sensors such as an IMU and commanding actuators such as motors. Control software (often referred to as an autopilot) is responsible for computing actuator speeds given desired vehicle velocity.

## Sensors

Reactive autonomy, such as collective flight, real-time collision avoidance, wall following and corridor centring, relies on telecommunication and situational awareness provided by range sensors: optic flow, lidars (light radars), radars, sonars.

## Applications

Electric vertical takeoff and landing aircraft, or eVTOLs, are being developed along with more autonomous flight control technologies and mobility-as-a-service (MaaS) to enable advanced air mobility (AAM), that could include on-demand air taxi services, regional air mobility, freight delivery, and personal air vehicles (PAVs).

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Summary

I successfully analyzed the paper "Unmanned Aerial Vehicles: Control Methods and Future Challenges" and completed all extraction tasks:

**Paper Classification:** `survey` - This is a literature review paper that discusses existing control approaches for UAVs rather than proposing novel methods.

**Extracted Triples (4 total):**

1. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (task) - The central subject of the paper's control systems review
2. **Control theory** (concept) - Provides the mathematical foundations for UAV control approaches
3. **Equations of motion** (concept) - Fundamental to modeling UAV dynamics and control design
4. **Autopilot** (tool) - Key technology enabling autonomous flight control in UAVs

All entities are properly linked to Wikipedia articles and include relevance descriptions. The validation script confirms all data is correctly formatted and all Wikipedia URLs are valid.
